Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2011 10:09PM 3rings wrote: absolutely, I didn't work through chemo and i have taken some sick leave when i change protocols to give my body time to adjust but I'm still working full time.  And as for vacations, my DH and i white water rafted the Colorado river through the Grand Canyon this year. Eight days on the river.  I was exhausted when it was over but it was wonderful.  In May I have rented and oceanfront house on the Outer Banks in NC for two weeks, a little more tame.  Going to take my girls and my husband parents the first week, family friends will be coming the second week. But at some point soon i will go on long term disability, i want to spend more time with family and I do run out of energy a lot faster than before.  I'm going to get as much in as I can while I can.

Posts.Title: Just got a call IwillBhealed vickib

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 03:08AM 3rings wrote: One of my twins, when she was 4 years old and i had gotten her up in the morning for pre school said to me, "Why do you get me up, make me get dressed and send me out there everyday, people are so hard."  Can you believe it at 4 years old. She is and was so right. I agree with everyone, its fear, fear of dieing, fear of being left, fear that they can't make it all better.  Everyone out there is fighting there own battle, Bless them, prey for them and move on.  Interestingly enough i have also had the opposite thing happen.  People who were not that involved in my life, stepping up, calling more often, making sure i don't need anything.  So i guess it goes both ways.
Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 01:11AM 3rings wrote: CoolBreeze, I like thinking about it as a 'limitation' that other people have for not being able to deal with our diagnosis.  This reminds me of another thread that wehad talking about people asking "What we had learned from having cancer?" Like it was some kind of character flaw that caused our BC.  Now we can respond............" I have learned that other people have limitations!"
Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2011 02:52AM 3rings wrote: Oh, i agree CoolBreeze the older i get the less i take anything anyone else dose or says or dosn't say personally.  We are all fighting our own battles.I know that at least one of ours is this disease, but there are many many people that are very physically healthy that i would not exchange places with.  One of my coping skills is feeling i'm lucky, i know this seams silly.  I may not live to see my girls marry, but i got to have them, i got to raise them, at least for a while. I like to think that I have had some positive contribution to their lives.  Way to many women are not so lucky.  So some people don't call as much as they used to, or not at all......there loss.
Posts.Title: People who disappear after diagnosis rosasmommy rosasmommy

Posts.Content: 3rings wrote: I usually live in De-Niel, its a very good place to be, i think of my cancer as a chronic condition and i'm healthy enough right now that this works well for me.  My brother called me today and told me he has be diagnosed with non operable Pancreatic cancer, stage 3.  All reality comes rushing back, after i get of the phone with him (he lives in another state) I look it up on the Internet hoping that with stage three there is some hope.  Nope the recommendation for stage 3 Pancreatic cancer is get into a clinical trial as quick a possible. I'm having a hard time absorbing this.......am i the lucky one.  No one hear wants to talk much about it, i guess it brings home to many realities, but CRAP.  He gets his treatment plan on Monday, and treatment will start on Wed.  At least I'm off work with my new protocol so i can go and see him as soon as he is up to it. CRAP I just can't take this in, i have no place to put it. If you knew that hope and despair were paths to the same destination, which would you choose? ~Robert Brault Dx 12/2009, IDC, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, ER+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Well HE** 3rings katie31

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 07:02PM 3rings wrote: You are right, he dosn't have any additional health problems so he can fight.  Maybe i'm over reacting, my brother in law was diagnosed with Pancreatic cancer two years ago, but he only lasted 3 weeks, the last one in a coma.  But every case is different right, just like us.   Thank you i'm starting to feel better, at least getting my head around it.  I guess this news and my bit of progression zapped me out of DeNiel smack into reality.  I wont be able to stay hear long, way to painful.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 02:06PM 3rings wrote: There is no way around it cancer sucks.  I must say that when i hit bottom what pulls me up is thinking "At least it is me, not one of my kids."  I also try and find things that I am thankful for, things like......... I am loved and that I love deeply, that I had many, many good years of good health.  Many arn't that lucky.  With my resent progression I have had to go to these places a few times.  I'm about to lose my hair again, but I'm thankful that with WBR it will only be the hair on my head not my nasal hair, which I found to be the most important hair on my body.  Constant post nasal drip without nasal hair.  I do miss my old life, but at least i had an old life to miss.  This whole approach is very Pollyanna, I know, but it seam to work for me.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 01:12PM 3rings wrote: Polyana, i have liver mets, only two spots now but when i was first diagnosed i had many.  prior to chemo i had a very strong loss of appetite, and the food I did eat did not taste right.  My stool was normal, at least i don't remember it being any different.  Even though i still have two spots  on my liver i don't have any symptoms from them, they are small and haven't changed at all for over a year.  I hope that your doctors are right that you have nothing to worry about.  CT scans are very sensitive much better than PET scans at picking up detail.  Sending you lots of positive energy!

Posts.Title: It's Working!!! Lynn1 debstar

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 06:20PM 3rings wrote: What a good friend you are.  But as my sisters have indicated once you are stage IV the outcome is not positive.  Not sure where your friend is but usually people find that one of the hardest times is between diagnosis and getting a treatment plan.  I think it is because once you have a plan you feel you have some control.  So being supportive during this time is very critical.  She is lucky she has you as a friend.
Posts.Title: Stage IV metastatic breast cancer smile2nite 3rings

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 08:56AM 3rings wrote: I go back and forth with this.  Most of the time if people ask how I am doing I just say 'i'm doing good, how are you?' and move on.  If they really want to know they press further.  But I had to laugh this Thanksgiving my sister in law asked for more information so i told her I was having headaches and was going in for an MRI of the brain next week.  She just said 'oh' and left the room.  Really I might have brain mets and all you can say is 'oh'.  I guess she just didn't know what to say or do with that information.  Then i run into people who say their Arthritis is acting up and then look at me and say. "well i know that is nothing compared to what you go through.'  Like my issues somehow lesson their life experience.  I tell them that me having cancer dosn't make their Arthritis any easier for them.  This is not a contest, and if it is I really don't want to win. Mostly I think we just want to be treated like everyone else,we want to be able to talk about what is going on in our lives and unfortunately that involves SE, dr. appointments, and treatments. But people can't relate I guess, so they leave.
Posts.Title: Help, Im boring. Cant talk about anything but cancer. LivingIt Reneepals

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2011 06:55PM 3rings wrote: It's great you have found an oncologist that you feel good about, i think that is so important.  I have been on monthly Zometa for about 18 months and have had great results, no new lesions and i've had some healing.  I was diag. at stage 4 and my symptom was pain when breathing, my chest x-ray showed what looked like inflammation, but the CT showed it as cancer.  i didn't have a cough.   But everyone is diff rent and there are many things that can cause shortness of breath.  Hang in there!  I'm sure others with more experience will respond soon.
Posts.Title: Start Zometa SusieMTN SusieMTN

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 03:52PM 3rings wrote: Oh this takes me back to when I told my girls, oldest 23 and the twins are 21.  There were old enough that they were going to see the facts on line, and i knew that eventually they would learn the odds.  I felt it was better that they got a softer version from me.  I told them individually, so that each could process in there own way. I told them that it was stage 4 and that there currently was not a cure, but that they had treatments and i had a treatment plan that i had every belief would be effective.  I  told them that they are always developing new things and that i had a lot of fight left in me. I also told them that there was no need to come home from school or to worry about me that nothing was that critical at this time as them getting their education which is very important to me.    I think this was harder then hearing the original stage 4 diagnosis.
Posts.Title: How do you tell them (long post)? reesie reesie

I so liked my time with the stable boy, i thought we were getting along well,looks like 'suspicious' and 'nonspecific' may be getting in our way! But alas Brighton is much more doable for me especial if it ends up being move in week for my girls. Posts.Title: Scared updowns MJLToday

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 06:27AM 3rings wrote: If it wasn't for that lovely river the diagnosis would be in our face all the time, and we wouldn't be able to function.  Then we have a doctor appointment, scan or a Zometa infusion and reality strikes.  eeek.  Once you have a plan, you feel a bit more in control, come up with new coping strategy for your new normal and find the path to the river again. Thats one of the best things about the folks on this board they will meet you at the river or during the scary parts.
Posts.Title: Scared updowns MJLToday

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 06:58PM 3rings wrote: I have hope and i believe anything is possible.  That being said, odds are i will die of beast cancer. Everyone is going to die of something.   Ask someone who has lost a loved one in a car accident if they would rather thier loved one was in our shoes, they would pick our shoes.  There is always something worse and i'm always glad that i'm not  that 'something'.  Does that make me a Pollyanna, maybe, but it's a truth i can live with. They will find a cure one day but another disease will take BC place, as we learned from Saturday Night Live.........It's always something.
Posts.Title: Do you have HOPE or CONFIDENCE in a cure? BaseballFan sandilee

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 01:16AM 3rings wrote: I'm just starting WBR had my 6th treatment this A.M. but from what i have read the side effects don't start until after the WBR is over and last for about 2 1/2 months, then there are another set of side effects that can kick in at about 6 months.  But as you have indicated many of us will be back on some kind of chemo by then so it's hard to know what is giving SE.  I have been very curious about this as well.  It looks like the SE very greatly.  Hope more people that have been there done that can comment.
Posts.Title: Side effects of WBR julie26 china

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2011 10:57AM 3rings wrote: Welcome Amy,  It is so overwhelming getting to the this point.  I remember being scared for about a week or two when I got my diag.  But with time found many ways to cope.  You have a strong sprit and that will be very helpful in this battle.  I have been very lucky with my bone mets, I have had some healing and no progression and it's been almost 2 years.  Best of luck to you and please keep us posted on your treatment plan.  I know I felt a lot better once I had a treatment plan.

You are in my thoughts, sending big ((((HUGS))))
Posts.Title: Do you ever just want to stop? palaminoridesagain Bren-2007

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 10:09AM 3rings wrote: You are dealing with a lot, it is no wonder you are depressed and upset.  If possible talk with a doctor and see if you can get some consoling or anti depression medication.  These are hard times and you need to get some help.  It is so wonderful that you can be with your mother at this time I am sure it give her great comfort.  Your mother loves you very much and would want you to get some help.   You are a good daughter,  many many ((((((HUGS))))))
Posts.Title: Mom diagnosed with MBC and I cant handle it no more... ssanie sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 06:09AM 3rings wrote: Thanks everyone, Waiting is the worse.  The only chemo i have had was 6 rounds of A,C and T right after my diagnose it was every 3 weeks, i was completely out of it the first week, awake more the 2nd week, and the third week i could go out to lunch then back for more chemo.  The PET I had last December showed that my lymph nodes in the AP window were either inflamed or were showing progression so i had a CT scan which showed no progression.  My oncol said if there was progression he would consider another 3 rounds of A,C and T if my heart showed i could take it. I think it is because we had gotten such great results the first time, but i guess i'll have to wait and see what he says.   I know that there are only so many 'tricks' in the bag and i hate to move to another one if the one i've had will still work.  Dumb stable boy,
Posts.Title: stable boy MIA 3rings Heidihill

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2011 10:55AM 3rings wrote: Just got back from my appointment and no chemo!!!  I started Faslodex today and i'm going to keep taking my Anastrozole, my oncologist says that he has three other people taking these together and they are having good results.  They gave me a list of side effects and one of them is loss of appetite, I told them that i wanted that one!  Wouldn't it be nice if we could pick our SE.

If you are interested i can get you a name and some additional information. Being comfortable in your treatment plan is very important.  Send me a PM if you want me to check into it.  Many hugs!
Posts.Title: stage 4-5-what the hell? sharalou 3rings

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 11:09AM 3rings wrote: So sorry you had to join us Cheriee, but glad you found this group, there is a wealth of knowledge, compassion and good humor.  I too have bone mets, bone scan lit up like a Christmas tree, as they say.  But, I'm stable my first line of treatment was chemo (i have mets to my lung, liver, lymph nodes too) 6 round of AC and T with Zometa.  That didn't do much for my bone mets but reduce the caner everywhere else.  I then went on Anastrozole (I'm ER+) and still get Zometa once a month, with this i have had some regrssion and healing of some bone mets.   It is very hard to get your head around your new normal, it's great that you work from home and have support. It's a long road and we all need to lean on someone, let this board be one of those lines of support, now one understand like us!

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 11:04AM 3rings wrote: Don't dispare, i was also diagnosed first time stage 4 with mets to liver, lungs, multiple lymph nodes in neck and chest, bone scan lit up like a Christmas's tree.  I did have a biopsy of my liver and then 6 rounds of A C and T chemo.  With marvelous results, the lump in my breast was gone, the pathology report said that the cells look just like the surrounding cells, the Pet Scan also showed no cancer in the Liver and greatly reduced in the lung.  I then went on to hormonal therapy, where the Pet Scan has shown that the cancer is not gone from my lungs and the bones are showing signs of healing. Now i do show a trace of cancer in my liver and lung on the CT scan (a bit more sensitive than the PET) but things are so much better, it's hard to complain.  But prior to having a plan of tretment i was scared and horrified, that gap between getting the diagnosis and starting tretment is like a waist land of dispare.   You will adjust to your new normal and find the strength to move forward.

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2011 12:37PM 3rings wrote: As hard as it is to have stage IV breast cancer, i honestly think it is harder to be the caregiver. I know the year before I was diagnoses my DH had a quad bypass surgery.  I stayed with him, working from home for almost a month.  It was so hard scheduling appointment's and getting prescription's filled. It was exhausting, and no one said, maybe you should take a break, which is what every caregiver needs.  But being a caregiver and having stage IV breast cancer has to be overwhelming.  As hard as it is, Please remember to take care of yourself!

Posts.Content: Jul 9, 2011 01:40PM 3rings wrote: wow this is very timely for me as well.  I'm have been working full time, but when i get home i'm to tired to cook dinner so we have been getting carry out a lot.  So the food is processed, or fried, it never occurs to me to get a salad.  My last scan showed some progression so i'm on to a new treatment plan with new side effects.  They are more of the same, more hot flashes, joint and muscle pain and fatigue.  I have decided to take some short term disability, to take care of my self and use what energy i have during the day to cook some health food, take a walk or do some gardining until i can adjust to the new SE.    It's time to put my self first. I figure the SE affect each person differently and each person is at a different health level when they get the treatment, so you can't judge how or what others can do vs what you should expect of your self.

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2011 06:01PM - edited Jul 1, 2011 06:10PM by 3rings It's very hard to make peace with a liar.  not sure if you got him into counseling but i think your girls are seeing his true colors.  There is an old saying that i used to tell my girls, (I so wanted them to know they didn't need a man to make them whole) and that is.......You can do bad all by yourself.  I mean really, as hard as it is to let go, what joy is he bringing to you life, and what lessons are you teaching your girls by staying with him. You deserve better and they need to know that there worth is greater than the likes of him.  You can't fix him, he is not broke, he's an ass and he is acting just like what he is.   I say all this but i also know that sometime there are financial reasons that don't allow for the split to occur.  Bottom line is you have to do what is right for you.  Just ignore me, it just makes me mad that anyone would treat anyone else this way, especially when they already have so much on there plate.

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 06:53AM 3rings wrote: I totally agree with Donnabee, I get Zomenta once a month so I hold the Faslodex in my hands while i  get my Zomenta infusion and this shots are sooo much easier. I went on Faslodex after my first progression as well.  Because I also have a lot of organ involvement I had Chemo first then went on AI, and was stable with some regression for about a year.  Then had progression so we started Faslodex and from everything I have read it does take some time to start working my doctor also kept me on my AI. Unlike the others I do have some SE, joint pain and fatigue, it may be because I'm taking it with my AI.  But everyone is different I started getting Faslodex the first of July and my doctor said it was to soon to do scans, so I have no idea if it is working.   Best of luck to you, please keep us posted on how you are doing.

Posts.Title: So my LTD provider called Fitztwins steelrose

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2011 09:28AM 3rings wrote: I too was diag stage 4 from the start with mets to lung, liver, chest lymph nodes and bone.  Chemo did a great job and test after showed no sign of the tumor in my breast.  My oncologist said that i may want to consider a  mastectomy.  There is a 'look back' study that showed that women who were stage 4 and had mastectomies lived longer.  However because this is a 'look back' study, it was not clear if only the 'healthiest' women those with fewer complications lived longer, that is to say they can't 'say' that the mastectomy was the reason for this outcome. I thought about this for a long time and decided because the tumor in my breast was gone, (The lab report indicated that the cells where the tumor was look like the surounding cells.)  that for now i would pass.  i'm not sure what i would have done if that was not the case. I tend to feel the less cancer in my body the better, and a lumpectomy would be much easier to take than a mastectomy.  Wouldn't it be great if this wasn't so much of a crap shoot!
